item.title: Coming Soon to CPA - Updated OSes and Ansible
item.description: Continuing the Crunchy Postgres via Automation (CPA) blog series, we’re back today with another ‘Coming Soon’ entry, where we discuss items that have been merged into development and will appear in a future release.

item.title: On CVEs, BoMs, and Releases
item.description: As previously mentioned in this Crunchy Postgres via Automation series, we now use a Bill of Materials (BoM) to ship tested-together versions of the components that comprise the CPA product.

item.title: Automating Highly Available PostgreSQL Clusters
item.description: In March of ‘23, I took over as the Lead Architect of my employer’s Ansible-based automation for creating highly-available PostgreSQL clusters.

item.title: Meetings, menu bars, and focus modes

item.description: After working on it for a bit, and convincing a coworker to use it and provide feedback, I’ve finally made gwt an actual thing.

item.title: I said brr it's cold in here
item.description: I don’t like the heat. I hate being hot. Always have.

item.description: One of the reasons that I find myself going back to Gentoo is that you compile the entire system for your hardware which, in theory, leads to the best performance possible.

item.description: As a belated update to this post, Mom has told DirecTV to completely go screw and she’s moved over to Philo where she’s currently loving life.

item.title: Monitoring pgBackRest with tail_n_mail
item.description: After a lively discussion at work today about monitoring tools and use cases, I decided to see if I could use tail_n_mail, which I already use to monitor my PostgreSQL logs, to monitor my pgBackRest logs.

item.description: I’ve noticed several individuals inquiring lately about pgBouncer and how they can avoid putting all users and their passwords in it’s auth_file.

item.title: I'm syndicated
item.description: Someone at work thought it would be a good idea to give me access to the corporate blog so that I might post PostgreSQL-related things there and have them syndicated to Planet PostgreSQL.

item.title: Linka
item.description: My Linka smart bike lock from Kickstarter showed up today. Holy Hell is this thing solid and hefty!

item.description: After an afternoon dicking around with Jekyll templates and Google searching, I’ve fixed up this site’s archive pages and tag cloud pages.

item.title: Where Not To Put Your Tablespaces
item.description: From the PostgreSQL docs: Tablespaces in PostgreSQL allow database administrators to define locations in the file system where the files representing database objects can be stored.

item.title: Making use of gists
item.description: After stumbling upon an example of how to do so, I’ve converted all my existing blog posts to use GitHub Gists instead of inline code blocks.

item.title: Happy 20th Birthday, PostgreSQL
item.description: Just a quick shout out to PostgreSQL, the world’s most advanced open source database, as it celebrates it’s 20th year in existence.

item.description: I don’t normally back things on Indiegogo (I’m a Kickstarter snob), but I jumped all over the eero.

item.title: Huawei Watch Review

item.description: Welcome to the new blog. That’s right, I’m running my own blog once again.

item.title: Doug Hunley
item.description: Born at the ass end of 1973, Douglas lived a (mostly) quiet life in and around the village of Weston, OH until moving to Columbus, OH to attend college in 1993.
